data.title: China’s Position on Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine
data.meta_description: Key Events and Statements Summarizing China’s Position on Russia’s Invasion of Ukraine from February 21, 2022 onward.
data.text:
Key Events and Statements from February 21, 2022 through April 30, 2024

Below is a list of key actions and statements summarizing China’s official position on Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine, which began on February 24, 2022. Items highlighted include China’s official government statements, press conferences, messages to the international community, media publications, and where available, leaked internal Chinese Communist Party (CCP) guidance for media and propaganda outlets.

(For a Timeline of key events prior to February 21 in the lead up to the invasion, visit https://www.uscc.gov/research/china-russia-interactions-leading-invasion-ukraine)

Entries are organized into the following categories:

[Action]: Chinese government activity which impacts the conflict in Ukraine

[Sanctions]: Chinese efforts to undermine international sanctions on Russia

[Statement]: Statements by Chinese government officials on the Ukraine conflict

[Media]: Chinese media stories reflecting official positions and censorship guidelines

[Event]: Major international events involving China, Russia, and Ukraine

[Timeline in reverse order, most recent event on top]

April 26, 2024

[Statement] U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken meets with China’s General Secretary Xi Jinping and other senior Chinese officials in Beijing and raises concerns about China’s support to Russia’s defense industrial base. In response to U.S. concerns, China’s Foreign Ministry spokesperson urges the United States to “stop scapegoating China and make real efforts to find a political end to the Ukraine crisis.”

April 16, 2024

[Statement] German Chancellor Olaf Scholz meets with General Secretary Xi Jinping in Beijing where the two sides discuss Ukraine. During the meeting, Xi reportedly reaffirms “four principles” that restate China’s previous positions for the restoration of peace in Ukraine.

April 15, 2024

[Sanctions] Reuters reports that the Russian Copper Company (RCC) and Chinese firms have disguised the trade of copper wire between Russia and China as scrap metal to avoid taxes and in an attempt to avoid reputational harm in light of recent sanctions prohibiting imports of Russian copper into the United States and United Kingdom. Chinese customs data shows China has imported significantly more copper scrap from Russia since December 2023.

April 12, 2024

[Sanctions] A report by the Financial Timescites senior U.S. officials saying China supplied 90 percent of microchips imported by Russia in 2023, and that these microchips were in tanks, missiles, and aircraft. The U.S. officials add that China is helping Russia to improve its satellite and space-based capabilities and providing satellite imagery to help Russia conduct war in Ukraine. Chinese entities are also “likely providing” Russia with nitrocellulose, a substance used to make propellants for weapons. The Chinese embassy in the United States disputes these claims and insists that China has “not provided weaponry to any party.”

April 9, 2024

[Statement] Russia’s foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov holds a press conference with China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi following talks in Beijing. Minister Lavrov says Russia is “grateful to [its] Chinese friends for their unbiased, balanced position” on Ukraine. According to China’s Foreign Ministry’s spokesperson, Minister Wang said that China “hopes to see an early ceasefire in Ukraine” and supports an international peace conference recognized by both Russia and Ukraine.

April 6, 2024

[Statement] U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen meets with China’s Vice Premier He Lifeng in Guangzhou, China, where she warns of significant consequences if China’s companies provide material support for Russia’s war against Ukraine.

April 1, 2024

[Statement] French Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs Stéphane Séjourné meets with China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Beijing where the two sides discuss Ukraine. During a press conference, Minister Séjourné says China plays a key role in upholding the respect of international law in regards to Ukraine’s sovereignty and that France expects “China [to] send very clear messages to Russia.”

March 22, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative of the Chinese Government on Eurasian Affairs Li Hui holds a press briefing for Chinese and foreign media and foreign diplomats in China in which he describes his second round of “shuttle diplomacy” on the war in Ukraine. He reiterates China’s support for the convening of an international peace conference that is recognized by both Russia and Ukraine, with equal participation from all parties. He claims that Russia, Ukraine, and relevant European countries all “expect China to play a greater constructive role” on Ukraine.

March 18, 2024

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to Switzerland Wang Shihting says in an interview that China is considering the possibility of participating in the Ukraine peace conference that Switzerland will host in June. When asked how to prevent the war in Ukraine from further escalating, Wang says that direct dialogue between Ukraine and Russia should be resumed as quickly as possible, and he indirectly condemned the “unilateral sanctions” imposed by the United States and others on Russia.

March 14, 2024

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to Ukraine Fan Xianrong meets with Ukraine President’s chief of staff Andriy Yermak to discuss Ukraine’s preparations for a proposed peace summit to be hosted in Switzerland in June.

March 11, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with Deputy Director General for Political Affairs and Security of the Ministry for Europe and Foreign Affairs of France, Jonathan Lacôte, in Paris, where the two sides discuss the war in Ukraine. Li says the “most urgent task now is to cool down the situation and find a way out for a ceasefire and an end to the fighting as soon as possible.”

March 9, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with State Secretary of the Federal Foreign Office of Germany Thomas Bagger in Berlin, where the two sides discussed Ukraine and the potential for peace talks, among other topics.

March 7, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with Andriy Yermak, chief of staff to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy in Kyiv. According to a readout by the Office of the President of Ukraine, the two sides discuss “the possibility of China’s assistance in putting an end to the forced deportation of Ukrainian children, in the exchange of prisoners, demilitarization and de-occupation of the Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant, guaranteeing nuclear security, and other international initiatives of [Ukraine].” China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs did not offer further details on China’s response in its official readout.

[Statement] China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi comments on China’s position on Ukraine at a press conference on the sidelines of China’s annual plenary sessions of the National People’s Congress and the Chinese People’s Political Consultative Conference known as the “Two Sessions.” He states China’s support for an international peace conference recognized by both Russia and Ukraine that would ensure the “equal participation of all parties.” He also emphasizes a need to properly address the “legitimate concerns” of all parties in order to establish a “balanced, effective, and sustainable security architecture” in Europe.

March 6, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with Poland’s Secretary of State of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Władysław Teofil Bartoszewsk, where the two sides discuss Ukraine. Li states China’s willingness to “promote peace talks” and to work with Poland and other countries to “cool down the situation and restore peace at an early date.”

March 4, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with officials from the European External Action Service in Brussels to discuss the war in Ukraine and ways to promote peace. Li reiterates China’s opposition to the EU including Chinese enterprises on its list of sanctions against Russia. The EU side urges China to take steps “within its jurisdiction to curb the flow” of items being exported from China to Russia’s military industrial complex.

March 2, 2024

[Statement] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui meets with Russian Deputy Foreign Minister Mikhail Galuzin in Moscow where the two sides discuss the possibility of a negotiated settlement to the war in Ukraine. A statement published by the Russian Foreign Ministry reportedly argues that China and Russia say it is “impossible” to discuss a Ukraine settlement without Moscow’s participation.

February 27, 2024

[Statement] China’s Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs Sun Weidong meets with Russia’s Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in Russia where the two sides discuss Ukraine and the Korean Peninsula.

February 25, 2024

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to the UN Zhang Jun criticizes the United States, the EU, and the UK for sanctioning Chinese companies and for using “the Ukraine crisis as a pretext.” He claims “China play[s] no part in the creation of the Ukraine crisis, nor is China party to the crisis itself.”

February 23, 2024

[Sanctions] U.S. Department of Commerce adds eight entities from China to its Entity List for activities supporting Russia’s defense-industrial sector and war effort. Five of the eight entities allegedly facilitated the diversion of controlled microelectronics to Russia’s military and intelligence authorities, while two others allegedly procured U.S.-origin machine tools, electronics test equipment, and machine tool spare parts for Russian end-users.

[Sanctions] The European Union approves its 13th package of sanctions in response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. Sanctions includes three Chinese firms and one Hong Kong-based company due to their role in trading electronic components of EU-origin products to Russia.

February 22, 2024

[Sanctions] The UK announces sanctions targeting individuals and businesses sustaining Russia’s war in Ukraine, including three Chinese companies. According to the UK Government, China’s Finder Technology and Juhang Aviation Technology allegedly supplied sanctioned electronics to Russia, and Beijing Micropilot Flight Control Systems’ unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) engines were found in UAVs used by Russian forces in Ukraine.

February 17, 2024

[Statement] China’s Minister of Foreign Affairs Wang Yi meets with Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba on the side lines of the Munich Security Conference. Wang Yi reportedly told Kuleba that China will “not add fuel to the fire, take advantage of opportunities to reap gains or sell lethal weapons in conflict zones or parties.”

February 16, 2024

[Statement] China’s Minister of Foreign Affairs Wang Yi meets with U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on the margins of the Munich Security Conference, where the two sides exchanges views on Ukraine. Secretary Blinken raises U.S. concern of China’s support for Russia and its defense industrial base amidst Russia’s ongoing war against Ukraine.

January 31, 2024

[Statement] In his first international engagement, China’s newly appointed Minister of National Defense Admiral Dong Jun held a video call with Russian Defense Minister General Sergei Shoigu. A video of Admiral Dong’s remarks released by Russia’s Ministry of Defense shows Admiral Dong affirming Chinese support for Russia “even though the [United States] and Europe continue to put pressure on the Chinese side” over Ukraine.

January 17, 2024

[Action] Chinese officials did not meet with Ukrainian officials to discuss potential peace talks despite the fact that both China’s Premier Li Qiang and Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy attended the World Economic Forum in Davos. Prior to Davos, Ukraine’s presidential chief of staff Andriy Yermak expresses the importance of China’s involvement in further meetings on Ukraine’s peace formula.

January 10-12, 2024

[Statement] China’s Minister of the International Liaison Department Liu Jianchao meets with the U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken on January 12 and the U.S. Principal Deputy National Security Advisor Jon Finer on January 10 in Washington DC, where the two sides reportedly exchanged views on Russia’s war against Ukraine. (Note: Liu made public comments on China’s position at a 9 January event, noted below.)

January 11, 2024

[Sanctions] The Kyiv School of Economics releases a joint study with the Yermak-McFaul International Working Group on Russian Sanctions that details how Russia continues to import components for military production despite current export controls. According to the study, supply chains for battlefield goods and critical components shifted in large part because of current export controls. Russia now imports most of these goods from China.

January 9, 2024

[Statement] During a public event on January 9, held by the Council of Foreign Relations in New York, China’s Minister of the International Liaison Department Liu Jianchao defends China’s position on Russia’s war in Ukraine. He says that while China “believes that the sovereignty and territorial integrity of a country must be respected,” in the context of the war in Ukraine, “the security concern [of Russia] must also be very well addressed.” He claims that when China talks to the Russians, “they [the Russians] are showing enthusiasm [for] having peace talks with Ukraine.”

December 30, 2023

[Statement] Following two UN Security Council emergency meetings convened to discuss Russia’s December 29 missile and drone attacks against Ukraine, China’s Deputy Permanent Representative to the UN Geng Shuang calls for an early end to hostilities and encourages peace talks to positively contribute to a “political settlement of the Ukraine crisis.”

December 20, 2023

[Sanctions] Ukraine’s National Agency on Corruption Prevention includes the China Railway Construction Corporation (CRCC) on its list of “international war sponsors” for its continued construction of subways, bridges, and highways in Russia.

December 19, 2023

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to Russia Zhang Hanhui says in an interview with Russian-state-owned news agency Sputnik that energy trade between China and Russia will “not be interfered [with] by third parties.”

December 12, 2023

[Sanction] The U.S. Department of Treasury designates a network of entities and individuals based in China, Russia, Hong Kong, and Pakistan for their involvement in the procurement and facilitation of Chinese-manufactured weapons and technologies to Russia. The Treasury sanctions Chinese national Hu Xiaoxun and his China-based private defense company Jarvis H K Co., Ltd. for coordinating a network of associates to circumvent U.S. sanctions and Chinese controls on the export of military-related materials. Hu’s company allegedly transferred funds for ammunition, loitering munitions, and semiconductor microchip manufacturing equipment. Treasury also designates 7 Chinese entities for shipments to Russia that support its war efforts in Ukraine such as providing high-resolution observation satellite imagery, advanced electronics, electronic components, and technological equipment and machine tools.

December 7, 2023

[Statement] The President of the European Council Charles Michel and President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen travel to Beijing to attend the 24th EU-China summit where the leaders discuss the war in Ukraine with China’s President Xi Jinping and Premier Li Qiang. The EU calls on China to prevent Russia from circumventing sanctions, refrain from supplying lethal weapons to Russia, and engage with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy’s 10-point peace formula. China's readout of Xi’s meetings did not provide additional details of China’s response to the EU’s requests.

[Sanctions] Data provided by China’s General Administration of Customs shows China-Russia trade reached $218.2 billion between January and November 2023, surpassing the total for all of 2022.

December 3, 2023

[Sanction] Russia’s military purchases 500 Chinese Desertcross 1000-3 utility terrain vehicles manufactured by Shandong Odes Industry. Russian news Agency TASS reports that Russia’s military already has around 537 basic models of the Chinese-made vehicles in service and plans to procure another 1000 in the first quarter of 2024. Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu notes the vehicles are “extremely in demand.”

November 29, 2023

[Event] Ukrainian senior official attributes the recent sabotage of Russia’s Baikal-Amur mainline, a key railroad line connecting China to the Trans-Siberian highway, to Ukraine’s Security Service (SBU) where several explosions were set along the Severnomuysky tunnel, less than 350 miles from China’s Heilongjiang province. Chinese officials have not commented on the incident; analysts have observed Russia using railways to transport Chinese equipment in support of Russia’s war in Ukraine.

November 24, 2023

[Action]: The Washington Post reports Ukraine’s security services intercepted communications between Russian and Chinese business executives with government ties discussing plans to build an underwater tunnel in the Kerch Strait connecting Russia to Crimea. China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs Spokesperson says the report is “groundless.”

[Statement] French Minister for Europe and Foreign Affairs Catherine Colonna meets with CCP Politburo Member, Director of the Office of the Foreign Affairs Commission and Foreign Minister Wang Yi in Beijing. During a press conference, Colonna calls on the Chinese authorities to ensure no Chinese contributions, particularly private, directly or indirectly contributes to Russia’s war effort in Ukraine.

November 15, 2023

[Statement] U.S. President Joe Biden meets with China’s General Secretary Xi Jinping in California where the two leaders discuss a range of bilateral and global issues, including Russia’s war in Ukraine. China’s Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Mao Ning later confirms the two leaders discussed the “Ukraine crisis” but did not elaborate beyond asserting China’s “commit[ment] to promoting talks for peace and de-escalation."

November 8, 2023

[Action] Russian President Vladimir Putin meets with China’s Central Military Commission Vice Chairman General Zhang Youxia in Moscow and discusses further military cooperation between the two countries. Putin points to China and Russia’s cooperation in high-tech sectors as a primary focus, alluding to the joint development of space and other weapons that could affect strategic stability. According to Russian reporting, General Zhang says he is in Russia to “carry out agreements [Putin] reached with President Xi” to hold regular meetings on military-technical cooperation and to “reinforce [China and Russia’s] military cooperation.”

October 30, 2023

[Statement] China’s Central Military Commission Vice Chairman General Zhang Youxia repeats calls for a political resolution for the Ukraine crisis and the Israel-Palestine crisis during his keynote address during Beijing’s 10th Xiangshan forum. He also makes a thinly veiled criticism of the United States, accusing a “certain country of intentionally creating turbulence” and “provid[ing] weapons and trigger[ing] proxy wars.”

[Statement] During Beijing’s 10th Xiangshan forum, Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu claims that Russia’s invasion of Ukraine was a legitimate response to the alleged expansion of NATO by the United States and its allies.

October 28, 2023

[Action] China declines to attend the third Ukraine Peace Summit hosted by Malta. The summit was attended by representatives from 66 countries, including the United States, United Kingdom, European Union countries, India, Brazil, Turkey, and South Africa. The Russian foreign ministry spokesperson called the Malta summit a “blatantly anti-Russian event.”

October 18, 2023

[Action] General Secretary Xi meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Beijing on the sidelines of the Third Belt and Road Forum for International Cooperation, where the two sides discuss the conflict between Israel and Hamas and the pursuit of further cooperation in emerging industries of strategic importance. Xi also requests greater progress in the China-Mongolia-Russia natural gas pipeline. While the official readout does not include mention of Ukraine, CNN reports that during a press conference Putin said he provided Xi with an update on the “situation that is developing on the Ukrainian track.” This is the second known trip outside of Russian-controlled territory Putin has made since the International Criminal Court issued a warrant for his arrest, the first was to Kyrgyzstan on October 12.

[Sanction] Russian export company, EPT, signed a 12-year contract with China’s Chengtong State Corporation to export 70 million tons of grain, legumes, and oilseeds to China. Since the start of 2023 Russian grain exports to have reportedly grown to a record 3.5 million tons as of September 24, higher than the 2.2 million tons exported in all of 2022.

October 16, 2023

[Statement] Ahead of the Third Belt and Road Forum, CCP Politburo Member, Director of the Office of the Foreign Affairs Commission and Foreign Minister Wang Yi meets with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in Beijing. Both sides discuss areas of cooperation including strengthening the collaboration of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization and supporting Russia’s rotating presidency of BRICS in 2024. A readout from the meeting from China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs does not include any discussion of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, however Russia’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs readout states the two diplomats “discussed the Ukrainian crisis, including the efforts to settle it through political and diplomatic means” noting that both sides position were “close or similar on all issues discussed.”

September 20, 2023

[Action] In a signal of continued business as usual between China and Russia, Wang Yi meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin in St. Petersburg. During the meeting Putin discusses how Russia is weathering the “shock of unilateral sanctions by the United States and the West” to start resuming economic growth and lends support to China’s Belt and Road cooperation.

[Action] Wang Yi also co-hosts the 18th round of China-Russia strategic security consultation with Nikolai Patrushev, the Secretary of the Security Council of the Russian Federation. According to China Daily, the two sides exchanges views on strengthening cooperation in law enforcement security, non-proliferation, and global governance of emerging technologies.

[Action] China and Russia held the 26th meeting of the China-Russia Economic and Trade Cooperation Sub-Committee of the China-Russia Prime Ministers' Regular Meeting Committee in Beijing, led by China’s Minister of Commerce Wang Wentao and Russia’s Minister of Economic Development Maksim Reshetnikov. Minister Reshetnikov discusses steadily growing Russian exports to China, expanding Chinese investment in Russia, enhancing the capacity of the transfer of goods at port, expanding the scale of local currency settlements, and promoting the further development of Russia-China economic and trade cooperation.

September 18, 2023

[Statement] CCP Politburo Member, Director of the Office of the Foreign Affairs Commission and Foreign Minister Wang Yi meets with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov in Moscow. During the Meeting, Lavrov praises China’s position paper on the “Political Settlement of the Ukraine Crisis” published on February 24 for “accommodating the security concerns of all partners and being conducive to eliminating the root causes of the conflict,” showcasing Russia’s confidence Beijing might back Russian interests in a future political settlement when applicable.

August 15, 2023

[Action] China’s then Minister of National Defense General Li Shangfu attends the 11th Moscow Conference on International Security, his second visit to Russia this year. In his public remarks he promotes Xi Jinping’s Global Security Initiative and repeated warnings on Taiwan and so-called efforts to contain China. General Li holds talks with Russia’s Defense Minister General Sergei Shoigu on the sidelines of the conference where they discuss further cooperation between the two countries militaries such as joint exercises and training.

August 7, 2023

[Statement] Following China’s attendance at the Ukraine peace summit in Saudi Arabia, CCP Politburo Member, Director of the Office of the Foreign Affairs Commission and Foreign Minister Wang Yi has a call with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov where the two sides “continue to work for close strategic coordination at international and multilateral levels.” In a readout released by China’s State Council, Lavrov says “Russia highly agrees with the position paper put forward by China on the political settlement of the Ukraine crisis…and welcomes China playing a constructive role in this regard.”

August 5, 2023

[Media] The Special Representative of the Chinese Government on Eurasian Affairs Li Hui attends the second Ukraine peace summit, hosted by Saudi Arabia, to represent China’s “position and propositions…on the political settlement of the Ukraine crisis.” The two-day summit in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, is attended by senior officials from over 40 countries, excluding Russia, and includes the U.S. National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan and the European Council’s foreign policy advisor to the president Simon Mordue. Chinese officials were invited but did not attend the first peace summit hosted by Copenhagen in June. While an unnamed EU official describes China’s participation as “active” and U.S. State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller calls China’s participation “productive,” it is unclear if China’s position influenced the peace process given differences between China’s position and Ukraine’s 10-point peace formula that includes the respect for the territorial integrity and sovereignty of Ukraine.

August, 2023

[Sanction] The International Energy Agency’s (IEA) Oil Market Report released in August 2023 reports that crude oil exports from Russia to China and India accounted for 80% of Russian shipments in July, though below reported levels in June.

July 31, 2023

[Action] China’s Ministry of Commerce announces restrictions on the exports of “certain types of drones and drone-related equipment including, lasers, communication instruments, hyperspectral cameras, and anti-drone systems,” to safeguard China’s national security interests. The restrictions will be in effect on September 1 and companies would need to apply for permits to export drones and other commodities as long as the drones are used for “legitimate civil purposes,” according to a Chinese Ministry of Commerce official. The restriction’s release came days after a July 27 public report by the U.S. Office of the Director of National Intelligence confirming the PRC had, as of March 2023, shipped more than $12 million in drones and drone parts to Russia.

July 20, 2023

[Statement] In the first high-level visit by a Ukraine government official to China since Russia’s invasion, Ukraine's Deputy Minister for Economic Development, Trade, and Agriculture meets with China's Vice Minister of Commerce Ling Ji in Beijing under the China-Ukraine Inter-government Cooperation Committee. Vice Minister Ling states China is willing to increase imports of quality goods from Ukraine and calls on Ukraine to take “concrete measures to safeguard the security of workers and properties of Chinese firms in Ukraine.” Ukraine’s Deputy Minister Kachka expresses hope to increase export of agricultural products to China. The meeting occurs the day after a Russian missile attack damaged China’s Consulate General building in Odesa. The meeting also occurs the same week Russia pulls out of the Black Sea Grain Initiative. The Initiative was brokered by the United Nations and had allowed the safe export of Ukraine grain since it was agreed to on July 22, 2022.

June 26, 2023

[Statement] China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Chinese media lend support to Russian President Vladimir Putin following the Wagner Group’s attempted coup. Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Mao Ning states the Wagner incident is “Russia’s internal affair,” noting China “supports Russia in maintaining national stability.”

June 9, 2023

[Sanction] According to the Wall Street Journal, in June 2023, shipments of eight unarmed “Tiger” armored trucks produced by Shaanxi Baoji Special Vehicles Manufacturing Co., Ltd appear in a video posted by Ramzan Kadyrov, the leader of Chechnya, who has contributed troops and equipment to Russia’s war in Ukraine.

May 24, 2023

[Statement] Russian Prime Minister Mikhahil Mishustin meet with General Secretary Xi as well as China’s Premier Li Qiang in Beijing. The two sides agree to a memorandum of understanding to deepen investment cooperation in trade serves, a pact on the export of agricultural products to China, and sports cooperation. Prime Minister Mishustin is the highest ranking Russian official to visit Beijing since Russia’s unprovoked invasion of Ukraine and is also on the U.S. Department of the Treasury’s sanctions list, since April 2022. The Russian delegation includes the Deputy Prime Minister Alexander Novak, who oversees Russia’s outbound economic development, and the Minister of Economic Development Maxim Reshetnikov, both of whom are also on the U.S. sanctions list. The visit is announced as G-7 leaders released a statement on Ukraine imposing “further sanctions and measures to increase the costs to Russia and those who are supporting its war effort.”

May 16, 2023

[Action] China’s Special Representative for Eurasian Affairs Li Hui becomes the highest ranking Chinese official to travel to Ukraine since Russia’s unprovoked invasion, where he meets with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and other senior Ukrainian officials according to China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Available reporting indicates there continues to be a gap between China and Ukraine’s positions on ending the conflict. Ukraine’s foreign minister Dmytro Kuleba stresses the importance of China’s participation in the implementation of Ukraine’s “peace formula,” which is based on respect for Ukraine’s sovereignty and territorial integrity.

April 26, 2023

[Action] General Secretary Xi Jinping speaks with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy for the first time since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

According to a readout of the call from China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Xi praises Beijing’s relationship with Kyiv and claims that China will “continue to facilitate talks for peace” and send a special representative to Ukraine and other countries. South China Morning Post confirms that Beijing will send Li Hui, China’s Special Representative on Eurasian Affairs and a former Chinese ambassador to Russia, to serve as the special representative in a future meeting with Ukrainian officials and “other countries.”

According to a summary of the call from Ukraine’s presidential office, President Zelenskyy requests that Xi assist in settling security concerns around Russia’s occupation of Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. Both parties supported the continuation of the Black Sea Grain Initiative, an agreement between Ukraine, Russia, Turkey, and the United Nations for facilitating exports of Ukrainian grain, related foodstuffs, and fertilizers.

April 23, 2023

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to the European Union, Fu Cong, tells Chinese state media that Beijing’s cooperation with Europe and other nations is “endless,” just like its relations with Russia have no limits. Ambassador Fu’s comments may represent an attempt by Beijing to restore confidence among EU member states following statements made by Lu Shaye, the Chinese Ambassador to France, after Lu questioned the sovereignty of post-Soviet states on Friday, April 21, 2023.

April 21, 2023

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to France Lu Shaye says in an interview with French television network LCI that “…these ex-Soviet Union countries do not have the status, the effective [status] in international law, because there is no international agreement to materialize their status as a sovereign country.”

Foreign ministers of Latvia, Estonia, and Lithuania, as well as the EU’s foreign policy chief, condemn the comments and describe them as “unacceptable” and “false.” Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to President Zelenskyy’s office, says on social media that China cannot expect itself to be taken seriously as a “major political player” if it parrots Kremlin propaganda.

On April 24, Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson Mao Ning states at a news briefing that “China respects the status of the former Soviet republics as sovereign countries after the Soviet Union’s dissolution,” and that this is the “official position of the Chinese government.” The Chinese Embassy in Paris issues a statement the same day rejecting Ambassador Lu’s comments as “an expression of personal views during a televised debate.”

April 18, 2023

Bloomberg reports that Russian officials “privately raised concerns” in Summer 2022 about becoming dependent on Chinese technologies following U.S. and European sanctions. A “previously unreported assessment” from the Russian Ministry of Digital Development, Communications and Mass Media states that Russian officials are concerned about companies such as Huawei dominating the Russian market and posing “a risk to the country’s information security and networks.” European officials “familiar with the document” say that the assessment was shared among the Russian General Staff of the Armed Forces and the Russian Security Council.

April 16, 2023

[Action/Statement] In his first visit to a foreign country as Minister of Defense, Li Shangfu meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin and Russian Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu in Moscow, according to South China Morning Post. According to the Washington Post, President Putin tells Minister Li that he hopes China and Russia can conduct more joint training exercises and professional exchanges. Minister Li said that China seeks to deepen its relationship to “strengthen strategic communication between the two militaries, strengthen multilateral coordination and cooperation, and make new contributions to safeguarding regional and global security and stability.”

April 14, 2023

[Action] Reuters reports that according to Russian customs data, Chinese firm Quzhou Nova purchased $7.4 million worth of copper alloy from a Russian-annexed region of Ukraine between October 8, 2022 and March 24, 2023. Debaltsevsky Plant of Metallurgical Engineering, located in the Donetsk region of eastern Ukraine, produces the copper alloy ingots. According to Reuters, the Russian Federal customs service cannot share information since it is confidential, and the Kremlin did not confirm if the purchase of the cooper alloy took place, claiming it has no information on the matter.

April 5, 2023

[Action] Beijing hosts French President Emmanuel Macron and European Union chief Ursula von der Leyen. President Macron says he can count on General Secretary Xi to bring Russia “back to its senses” and get “everyone back to the negotiating table.” Reuters also notes that President Macron tells the press after his arrival to Beijing that Europe must “resist reducing trade and diplomatic ties” with China. Politico asserts, however, that during the second day of Macron’s visit on April 6, 2023, General Secretary Xi “gave no hint he would use his influence to help end the conflict.” Politico says that General Secretary Xi Jinping and the CCP “enthusiastically endorsed” Macron’s concept of strategic autonomy.

March 21, 2023

[Action] TheNew York Times reports that Russia has purchased $12 million worth of drones from Chinese manufacturers, including DJI Technology and Autel, since the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine on February 24, 2022.

[Statement] Chinese General Secretary Xi Jinping and Russian President Vladimir Putin issue a joint statement outlining Beijing’s self-proclaimed “unbiased position” on the war in Ukraine. The statement also vaguely notes that the countries will commit to further studies on the proposed Power of Siberia-2 natural gas pipeline, although Putin reportedly sought a specific commitment from Xi on constructing the pipeline, according to the Financial Times. Additionally, General Secretary Xi invites President Putin to come to China “at a convenient time” in 2023.

March 20, 2023

[Action/Statement] Reuters reports that Russian President Vladimir Putin hosted Chinese General Secretary Xi Jinping for a dinner at the Kremlin, holding informal talks that lasted over four hours. Reuters also notes that General Secretary Xi’s decision to make the visit takes place despite an International Criminal Court (ICC) arrest warrant issued on Friday, March 17 that accuses Putin of war crimes for deporting children from Ukraine. Chinese Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Wang Wenbin says during a press conference that the ICC “needs to take an objective and just position, respect the jurisdictional immunity of a head of state under international law,…” and should “not engage in politicization or use double standards.”

March 16, 2023

[Action] Politico reports that according to customs data, China North Industries Group Corporation Limited (NORINCO) sent 1,000 CQ-A rifles to Russia between June and December 2022. Politico also reports that Chinese companies sent 12 tons of body armor to Russia over the same time period. March 13, 2023

Wall Street Journal reports that Chinese General Secretary Xi Jinping plans on speaking with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, according to “people familiar with the matter.” Wall Street Journal says that the discussion would likely take place virtually following General Secretary Xi’s visit to Moscow, but China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs did not immediately respond to a request to comment. A Ukrainian official who spoke to the Journal states that the call is yet to be scheduled.

March 7, 2023

[Statement] Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang states that “currencies should not be trump cards for unilateral sanctions, still less a disguise for bullying or coercion.” Qin states that trade between China and Russia will use “whatever currency is easy to use.” An increasing share of Russian trade with China is denominated in RMB, as Russian financial institutions and businesses have struggled to access dollars and euros under Western financial sanctions.

March 1, 2023

[Action] MMC Norilsk Nickel, Russia’s largest mining company, is accepting payment denominated in Renminbi (RMB) for its sales of nickel to China, according to Bloomberg. Russian companies’ ability to transact in dollars, in which the vast majority of commodities trading is priced, have been severely curtailed under U.S. and partner countries’ financial sanctions on Russia. MMC Norilsk Nickel’s willingness to accept prices set in RMB will likely boost its sales to China. In 2022, 14 percent of Russia’s total exports were paid for in RMB, an increase from 0.4 percent at the beginning of that year. Over the same period, bilateral trade rose to $190 billion, a 30 percent increase compared to 2021.

[Statement] Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko states that Belarus “fully supports” China’s peace proposal while visiting General Secretary Xi in Beijing. According Xinhua News Agency, both sides agree to jointly implement China’s Global Development Initiative and Global Security Initiative. General Secretary Xi says that “China is ready to strengthen coordination and cooperation with Belarus at multilateral fora, including the United Nations, to jointly address global challenges and build a community with a shared future for mankind.”

The Global Security Initiative, a security framework proposed by General Secretary Xi at the Boao Forum for Asia’s annual conference in April 2022, is increasingly a key part of China’s foreign engagements. This initiative endorses the concept of “indivisible security,” which Russia has cited in its negotiations over Ukraine. The concept of “indivisible security” and the Global Security Initiative are broader than the Ukraine crisis and appear to be attempts by China and Russia to coopt portions of concepts from agreements inked in the 1970s to establish, influence, or distort contemporary international norms in the security realm.

February 25, 2023

Central Intelligence Agency Director Bill Burns confirms in a CBS News interview that China is considering sending lethal aid to Russia to support the Kremlin’s efforts in Ukraine. He says that China has yet to decide on transferring lethal equipment to Russia, and that there are no “actual shipments of lethal equipment” found yet.

February 24, 2023

[Action] On the one-year anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs releases “China’s Position on the Political Settlement of the Ukraine Crisis,” a twelve-point paper that calls for all parties to support dialogue between Russia and Ukraine to “gradually deescalate the situation.” Though it does not name the United States and Europe, it repeats criticisms of a “Cold War mentality” and the economic measures taken against Russia. Without naming Russia, the paper repeats opposition to any use of nuclear weapons and any attacks on nuclear power plants. The paper offers little by way of substantive diplomatic proposals and repeats many of Beijing’s standard positions on Ukraine.

February 23, 2023

[Action] China’s top diplomat and CCP Politburo member Wang Yi meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin and other Russian leaders. Wang describes China-Russia relations as “rock-solid.” In a press conference later that day, Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesperson Wang Wenbin says that the two sides agreed to “firmly oppose hegemonism and bloc confrontation,” and “jointly uphold the purposes and principles of the UN Charter,” among other core concepts outlined in the Global Security Initiative, which the Russian government has not formally endorsed.

February 21, 2023

[Action] China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs publishes the Global Security Initiative Concept Paper, which elaborates on China’s “alternative” to military alliances. The paper restates the six commitments expressed last year at the Boao Forum and adds two new sections on “Priorities for Cooperation” and “Mechanisms for Cooperation.” The paper reiterates China’s position of supporting “a political settlement of hotspot issues such as the Ukraine crisis through dialogue and negotiation.”

February 19, 2023

U.S. Secretary of State Anthony Blinken says in an interview with CBS News that the United States has information indicating China is considering providing lethal support to Ukraine.

February 18, 2023

[Statement] China’s top diplomat and CCP Politburo member Wang Yi delivers a speech at the Munich Security Conference, an annual conference on international security policy held in Munich, Germany. In his speech, Wang promotes General Secretary Xi’s Global Security Initiative and states, without elaborating on specifics, that “on the Ukraine issue, China’s position boils down to supporting talks for peace.”

February 17, 2023

[Action] Officials from China’s Ministry of Commerce meet with ten Chinese independent oil refiners regarding the volume and prices of their imports of Russian oil, according to sources that spoke with Reuters. The officials refrain from offering guidance on the oil imports. The price cap is intended to reduce the revenue Russia receives from oil exports without fully cutting off supply from Russia and avoiding a spike in the price of oil.

February 14, 2023

[Action] Reutersand Bloomberg report that Chinese state-owned petrochemical giants Sinopec, PetroChina, and China National Offshore Oil Corporation (CNOOC) are resuming purchases of Russian crude oil. China’s major state-owned petrochemical companies had halted purchases of Russian crude after the G7, the EU, and Australia first implemented a price cap mechanism on December 5, 2022, which is aimed at limiting the revenue Russia receives on oil exports. Oil importers that purchase oil above a set price will be ineligible for shipping and services, including insurance, from G7 -based companies. However, the cargoes purchased by these Chinese refiners are purchased through trading companies that arrange payments to Russian oil producers as well as insurance and shipping, side-stepping the limitation imposed by the price cap mechanism. Oil industry consultants Energy Aspects estimate that China’s daily imports of Russian oil may rise by 500,000 barrels or more over the course of the year, reaching 2.2 million barrels per day. China’s total crude imports are projected to reach as high as 11.8 million barrels per day.

February 8, 2023

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to the European Union Fu Cong expresses concern about the West calling for Ukraine to attain a “complete victory on the battlefield” and instead suggests finding a solution “on the negotiation table” at an event hosted by the Brussels-based think tank European Policy Centre. Fu Cong also said “And we don’t believe that only providing weapons will actually solve the problem.”

G7 member states discuss whether to sanction Chinese, Iranian, and North Korean companies for providing parts and technology to Russia for military use. Anonymous individuals familiar with the matter tell Bloomberg that the G7 member states may seek to coordinate a package of measures by February 24, 2023, on the one-year anniversary of Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, according to Bloomberg. The individuals note, however, that G7 member states may take different actions and still need to decide what companies to include.

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to France Lu Shaye says in an interview with French news channel LCI that China has “not supplied weapons to Russia.” When pressed on whether Chinese companies are selling spare parts that support Russia’s war effort, Lu states “parts are not weapons, are they?” Lu states that China believes that weapons supplied by NATO countries “to one side of the war is not conducive to ending the war as soon as possible.”

February 4, 2023

[Action] The Wall Street Journal reports that multiple Chinese state-owned and non-state companies have exported military and dual-use technology items to Russian defense companies. [Statement] Financial Times reports that an anonymous Chinese official said Russian President Vladimir Putin is “crazy.” The official also asserts that China shouldn’t “simply follow Russia,” and acknowledges that only a handful of Russian officials made the decision to invade.

December 1, 2022

November 29, 2022

November 16, 2022

[Statement] Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi says China endorses Russia’s no nuclear pledge on Ukraine at the Group of Twenty (G20) summit. November 15, 2022

November 14, 2022

[Action] Chinese independent and state refiners cut back on purchases of Russian crude oil as the imposition of the G-7’s price-cap mechanism on Russian oil nears, according to Reuters reporting. October 27, 2022

[Statement] China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi expresses in a phone call with Russian Minister of Foreign Affairs Sergey Lavrov that China will firmly support Russian President Vladimir Putin’s government to help lead the Russian people to “overcome difficulties, eliminate disturbances, realize the strategic goals of development, and further establish Russia on the international stage.” Wang Yi also says that China is willing to deepen exchanges with Russia at all levels. October 21, 2022

[Statement] China’s Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Wang Wenbin expresses China’s disagreement with the European Union’s decision to sanction three Iranian generals and an Iranian company for supplying drones to the Russian military for use in its invasion of Ukraine. October 10, 2022

[Statement] Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning calls for de-escalation in Ukraine, stating “all countries deserve respect for their sovereignty and territorial integrity” and that “support should be given to all efforts that are conducive to peacefully resolving the crisis.”

September 26, 2022

[Statement] Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin avoids media queries about diplomatic communications between Ukraine and China. September 22, 2022

[Statement] China’s Foreign Minister Wang Yi outlines China’s four priorities in resolving the Ukraine conflict before the UN Security Council: providing support for negotiations; urging the de-escalation of conflict, particularly around nuclear facilities; alleviating the humanitarian crisis; and curbing the “spillover effects” of the war, such as the global food crisis. [Statement] Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Wang Wenbin that China calls “on the parties concerned to achieve a cease-fire and an end to the war through dialogue and negotiation, and find a way to take into account the legitimate security concerns of all parties,” as reported by the Wall Street Journal, the Agence France-Presse, and Al Jazeera. Although the official readout from the Foreign Ministry press conference excludes the term “cease-fire”, Foreign Ministry spokesperson Mao Ning also used the phrase during a September 13 press conference.

September 18, 2022

U.S. President Joe Biden says in an interview with 60 Minutes, “Thus far, there’s no indication [China has] put forward weapons or other things that Russia has wanted.”

[Support] General Secretary Xi Jinping meets with Russian President Vladimir Putin on the sidelines of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO) Summit in Uzbekistan. September 14, 2022

Members of Ukraine’s parliament Oleksandr Merezhko and Mykola Kniazhytskyi join the Inter-Parliamentary Alliance on China, a group of lawmakers from 30 legislatures which collaborates on policy responses to China. September 7, 2022

[Support] China’s top legislator Li Zhanshu travels to Vladiostok to attend Russia’s Eastern Economic Forum on foreign investment in the region. Li asserts that “the political trust, strategic coordination and pragmatic cooperation between the two countries have reached new heights” and states that China fully understands and supports Russia’s need to secure its core interests, including Russia’s actions in Ukraine.

September 6, 2022

[Sanctions] Chinese state-owned China National Petroleum Corporation agrees to pay for half of the gas it buys from Russian company Gazprom using renminbi (RMB), and will use rubles for the other half. Russian businesses and financial institutions have struggled to access dollars due to Western sanctions imposed in response to its unprovoked invasion of Ukraine.

August 30, 2022

Chair of Ukraine’s Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Policy and Interparliamentary Cooperation Oleksandr Merezhko states to the Voice of America that “Ukraine should seriously reconsider [its] strategic partnership” with China over China’s support for Russia. August 27, 2022

[Action] Newsweek reports that Chinese diplomats are pressuring members of Ukraine’s parliament over their membership in the Taiwan Friendship Group, a parliamentary caucus created on August 18, 2022 to promote ties with Taiwan. Chair of the Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Policy and Interparliamentary Cooperation Oleksandr Merezhko tells Newsweek that the complaints from Chinese diplomats indicate that China is “trying to dictate what a foreign parliament should do.”

August 24, 2022

Bloomberg reports that Russia’s Ministry of Finance is considering issuing government bonds denominated in RMB, although it has not announced plans to do so in 2022. Russia has considered issuing RMB-denominated bonds since Russian companies were impacted by sanctions imposed in response to Russia’s 2014 invasion of Ukraine.

August 23, 2022

[Statement] China’s Ambassador to the United Nations Geng Shuang notes the risk of a “serious nuclear accident” stemming from the fighting near the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant. Geng states, “Under the current circumstances, it is necessary for the IAEA to conduct a site visit to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant as soon as possible to make a professional and technical assessment of the safety and security situation of the nuclear facilities.”

In July 2022 Russia was responsible for 3.9 percent of all payments using RMB outside of China, compared to less than 1 percent in January 2022. Russian businesses and financial institutions may be exploring opportunities to use RMB in their international transactions after international sanctions curtailed Russian banks’ access to U.S. dollars and euros.

Fifteen members of Ukraine’s parliament form a cross-party caucus called the Taiwan Friendship Group, which is aimed at promoting closer ties with Taiwan. Chair of the Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Policy and Interparliamentary Cooperation Oleksandr Merezhko states that the group was formed in gratitude for the sanctions Taiwan has introduced against Russia for its invasion of Ukraine.

August 17, 2022

[Action] China’s Ministry of Defense announces that the People’s Liberation Army (PLA) will participate in Russia’s annual strategic level military exercise, VOSTOK- 2022, and claims the PLA’s participation “is unrelated to the current international and regional situation.”

August 16, 2022

The United States sanctioned DJI drones in 2020 for facilitating repressive regimes and human rights abuses.

August 8, 2022

[Sanctions]Bloomberg reports that Chinese exports to Russia in July were valued at $6.7 billion, which is comparable to the level of Chinese exports to Russia from before Russia’s invasion of Ukraine. August 5, 2022

[Statement] Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hua Chunying defends Russia when asked about the U.S. Senate resolution to designate Russia as a state sponsor of terrorism. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy states during an event at the Australian National University that he “would like China to join the unified world position” on Russia’s tyranny against Ukraine. [Action] South China Morning Post reports that China’s People’s Liberation Army has sent military tanks and a delegation to Russia to participate in Russia’s International Army Games in August. [Statement] China’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs has not commented on the Russian missile attack on Ukraine’s key grain-exporting port of Odessa on July 23. Financial Times reports that China has not approved any new Belt and Road Initiative (BRI) deals with Russia since Russia invaded Ukraine. CIA director William Burns asserts that China is learning from Russia’s invasion of Ukraine lessons that may apply to an invasion of Taiwan. [Statement] China’s Foreign Ministry Spokesperson Zhao Lijian comments on U.S. Agency for International Development Administrator Samantha Power’s assertion that China worsened the global food crisis by hoarding grain and fertilizer.
